Message.Msg: European Parliament President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression Jan. 19, 2013, Schulz says EU on path to depression: report European Parliament President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression, according to an interview with Saturday's edition of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. "[The E.U.] is on a path to a depression, apathy, a mood of not caring. That's dangerous, as that mood superimposes the great successes of the E.U., for which it recently won the Nobel Peace Prize," Mr. Schulz is quoted as saying.

Message.Title: Profit taking before Options - don't panic!
Message.Msg: Had this scare last options expiry. I held. In it for the long run. This stock has peaked for now. However, due to the run up of this and others, uncertainty, politics, world (IMF rpt) Davos news etc. A sell stop advised to avoid losses and if you are into options, I would buy protection Just in case. This is not a stock to trade anymore unlike Rimm, Nok, or similar. It has run it's course. Possibly break 11 by Friday but will remain range bound. Will not drop below $10.50 due to valuation and long term institutional holders. Banks will hold +,- 10% through March. Opinion.

Topic.Title: I bought a lot of bac over 12 because CNBC carnival barkers kept pumping pumping

Message.Msg: I wrote last week about Cramer, who on January 7 or 8 and live on CNBC, gave BAC a huge buy rating when it was above $12. The next day it began its debacle. How do we interpret such irresponsible commentaries? Investors rely on analysts' projections to further their investments. It's almost criminal. Jim Cramer is not alone. I went on to write last week that CNBC analyst Pete Najarian last summer, when ZNGA was at $6 and in the midst of introducing their new lineup of video games during a media conference, stated many times over that he had a price target of no less than $12 for them. ZNGA began crashing moments after Najarian's last analysis of them, soon after their conference came to a close. Today it is at or near 2.40. A far cry from 12$. These analysts can teach me a thing or two about different graph patterns, options, puts and calls, etc. but when it comes down to what we mostly expect of them, which is to guide us with regards to where we should invest, they are most incompetent or rather just not worthy of being anyone's analyst. I think I am just as much an analyst as they are. The truth of the matter is it is all guesswork. Certainty lies mostly in fundamentals and 2-3 year projections. Never short term. Look at them all today scrambling as far as RIMM is concerned. I'm certain they would love nothing more than to entice everyone to buy RIMM rendering it hugely overbought and ripe for a debacle so they can buy it all back. Are they trustworthy and impartial? Probably not. I think the last 4 years almost speaks for itself when determining how incompetent they truly are. I am just here to remind those who tend to forget such facts.

Message.Title: Americans more downbeat than at any time since Carter, poll says..Gallup..
Message.Msg: And it's going to get worse before it gets any better. Democrats and the media forget almost 50% of our Country voted Republican and the Republicans will not let this Country become a Socialist Dictatorship..... Washington – As President Obama begins his second term, he is facing an increasingly pessimistic public who believes that America's best days are behind them. According to a recently released Gallup poll, 39 percent of Americans rated the current climate of the country as positive. That's about the same as it was in 2010 -- and has been the lowest recorded by Gallup since President Jimmy Carter's term in 1979.
